Description:
[Wonton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wonton) are typically deep-fried or boiled and served in soup. The literal translation *cloud swallows* alludes to how the wonton float in soup with the skin billowing (according to Grace Young in The Wisdom of the Chinese Kitchen, wontons made correctly should be “heavenly morsels”).

**Cooking Tips**

You can buy wonton skins (squares) from Asian grocery stores.

**Characters**

The characters [雲吞](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/雲吞) for [wonton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wonton) literally mean *cloud swallows* which is a nice rebranding -- long ago the name evolved from 餛飩 which is pronounced the same in Cantonese and means *chaos*, alluding to how wonton was enclosed without a way to breathe.

images.place: Tim Ho Wan, Las Vegas, Nevada

Description:
These Sichuan wontons are boiled and marinated in chili oil, so they are often listed as *wontons in chili oil*.

**Characters**

[紅](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/紅) is *red*, and [油](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/油) is *oil*, so [紅油](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/紅油) is *red oil* or *chili oil* and [抄手](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/抄手) is another word for *wonton* (the literal meaning is to fold one's arms), and altogether 紅油抄手 is *red oil wonton*.
